ygData.subject: Re: Somethin seems wrong (long response)
ygData.msgSnippet: I ve worked my models on the assumption that there are a limited amount of smiths out there and there won t be 4 smiths in a zone. You ve seen how many
ygData.messageBody:
I've worked my models on the assumption that there are a limited amount of smiths out there
and there won't be 4 smiths in a zone. You've seen how many auctions there are for banded. Try
ignoring them once and seeing how long they can run on for. This isn't a matter of
competition, it's a matter of 'they want it if they can get a fair price'. The point of price
fixing is to fix that 'fair price' at a higher amount than it is currently. The more people
that sell higher, the more accustomed people will become to paying it, and the more 'fair'
they feel it will be. If there's another smith in a zone when I first walk in, and I intend on
selling any banded, I politely change zones no matter what their price. I will not undersell
them out of courtesy and it'd be pointless to oversell them. I don't even sell at equal prices
because I might be taking sales they would have otherwise gotten. This is just my politeness,
though, if you want to make a few enemies, go ahead and undersell every smith you see. All
you'll get is a crashing market on your head and a poisoned dagger in your back.

Back to the point, though, your argument with me so far has been that price fixing won't work
because people will always sell for lower and customers will refuse to buy for the higher
price. The truth is, people are starting to sell for higher all across the boards, and
customers are buying at a greater profit to those of us who have decided to price raise.
Whether you realize it or not, that's a fact, and you can't dispute it. You can't tell me
green is blue any more than you can tell me people won't buy my banded because it's higher
priced. So, to conclude, pick your side. Side A spends an hour a day making banded, Side B
spends 5 hours. Both sides make the same profit.

-Rennin of E'Ci
Trade Council GM

Peter Wong wrote:

> From: Peter Wong <lkworthpete@...>
>
> From: Nick Emmerich <seorin@...>
>
> First of all, the RL name thing isn't meant to offend you. People call me
> 'Nick' all the time,
> be it in e-mail, message boards, or whatever. It's my name, I don't really
> care. If you do,
> however, I'll respect that and stick to Cerran. I'm not out to offend you,
> I'm just trying to
> prove a point
>
> I'm not especially known for banded on my server, I'm at an equal platform
> with everyone else.
> If I can sell at a price, other people can too. So, when I sell at higher
> prices, that proves
> to other smiths that they can as well. Instead of undermining my price and
> making less money
> per sale, they can go to a different zone and sell for the same price I am.
> Sales are out
> there, and if the market isn't oversaturated then they always will be. Why
> get less money and
> contribute to market oversaturation at the same time? Both are negative
> things to a smith.
> Charging less money, we both lose, charging the same price, we both win. I
> don't see how
> somebody can justify competition between smiths as 'a good business
> strategy'. If they charge
> the same price as me, they'll make more money than if they charged less!! I
> make more money
> since the price raise, it shouldn't be different for anyone else. As for new
> smiths who
> haven't mastered the trade yet, I have no idea where you're getting your
> idea from. Why would
> any reasonably intelligent person charge less for an item when they're in a
> higher need for
> money? This is what you're telling me. Since they need money, they will
> charge a lower price.
> Usually I put more logic into my arguments, but I can't even touch that
> because it simply does
> not make sense. Newer smiths would want to charge higher prices so they can
> get more money so
> they can spend more money on practicing their smithing! I'm assuming that
> every new smith on
> this board is in favor of the price raise. If you're a new smith and you
> aren't in favor of
> price raising, frankly, you have your head shoved right up your ass. You're
> ruining the market
> you're just getting into by selling at lower prices, and you're making less
> money now and in
> the long run. There is no justification for that, it's just plain idiotic.
> -Nick Emmerich
> a.k.a. Rennin of E'Ci
> Trade Council GM
>
> Unfortunately Nick you've displayed your total lack of knowledge of how price
> affects a supply and demand model. If you don't know what I'm talking about,
> it's the most basic model of economics. Anyone who doesn't, I would suggest
> you go find out. So that you understand what the logic is behind your
> competition driving their prices down in order to stimulate more demand for
> their armor over yours. You might also want to read up on the concept of
> liquidity and how it affects one's business. That might also explain the idea
> of selling at a discount to raise cash. Artificially setting prices does not
> work. Any smith with half a brain will know that if there are four "smiths"
> in the same area that seem to be selling well at <x> price he/she can sell
> better than them at a discount. We wouldn't be having this discussion if
> there weren't people already doing this that are affecting the market.
>
> Cerran
